title: Infectious Diseases in Public Health Practice
requirements: For TPg students in Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health
description: This course is designed to develop basic knowledgebase in infectious diseases in the society, in contexts of causation, impacts, diagnosis and epidemiology.
outcome: Students are expected to 1) Have a basic familiarity with major infectious disease pathogens 2) Know the differences between viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites 3) Understand how the human immune system protects against infection 4) Be introduced to infectious diseases of public health significance
syllabus: Overview of microbiology, immunology, diagnostics. Emerging Infectious diseases     Infectious diseases of public health importance part 1   Infectious diseases of public health importance part 2

recommended_readings: Public Health Infectious Disease by Prof SS Lee.ISBN   9789881594815

title: Infection Control in Health Care and Community Settings
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health
description: Students would be introduced to the principles and practice of infection control in three settings–hospital and clinic, laboratory and the community, through a series of lectures tailored to the needs of public health professionals. The emphasis would be on the development of a systematic approach to infection control practice.
outcome: Student should be able to: 1. update on the principles of infection control in health care setting, laboratory and community 2. familiarize with system development in infection control practice
syllabus: L1: Disinfection and sterilization    L2: Standard precautions and transmission based precautions   L3: (I) Immunity and immunization and  (II) Vaccination of health care workers   L4: Infection control in (I) special hosts and (II) community and special environment   L5: Outbreak management (I) case finding and control measures; (II) Decision making in infection control    L6: Control of airborne infections in hospital and institutional environments Post-exposure prophylaxis   L7: Surveillance in infection control (I) programme design and data collection; (II) data analysis and presentation   L8: Antimicrobial resistance (I) mechanism; (II) containment programmes    Root Cause Analysis    L9: Engineering design for isolation and operation theatre
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher
recommended_readings: Hospital Epidemiology and Infection Control. C. Glen Mayhall, ed. Philadelphia. Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. C 2012, 4th Ed. CHP and HA Isolation Precautions guidelineshttp://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/isolation_precautions.pdf Control of transmission of TB in healthcare settings in the Hospital Authorityhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/transmission_tb_20051103.pdf WHO Policy on Tuberculosis Infection Control in Health-Care Facilitieshttp://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2009/9789241598323_eng.pdf Recommendations on the Postexposure Management and Prophylaxis of Needlestick Injury or Mucosal Contact to HBV, HCV and HIVhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/recommendations_on_postexposure_management_and_prophylaxis_of_needlestick_injury_or _mucosal_contact_to_hbv_hcv_and_hiv_eng_r.pdf

title: Application of Geographic Information System in Public Health
requirements: For TPg students in Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health
description: "Geographical information system (GIS), integrating cartography, statistical analysis, and database technology, has been widely applied in the study of public health, for example, disease surveillance, risk assessment, and decision making for public health practices. This course aims to offer a general introduction to GIS, including basic concepts, methodologies, and applications of GIS in public health issues.No special prerequisite for this course. Class size can NOT be larger than 40."
outcome: Through this course students are able to: 1. understand the principle and importance of GIS in public health research; 2. develop a concept understanding of basic GIS in geocoding; 3. conduct basic geostatistical analyses of geo-referenced data of public health and disease mapping in practice;
syllabus: Introduction1. What is geographical information system (GIS);2. GIS application in public health;3. Project arrangement   Understanding spatial data for public health and mapping health information1. Characteristics and examples of spatial data;2. Where to access spatial data?3. Coordinate systems, projections, and transformation;   Lab tutorial 11. Getting QGIS started;2. Importing spatial data to QGIS;3. Mapping health information in QGIS   Locating health information1. Geocoding;2. Generating spatial data in QGIS;3. Mapping and cartography   Spatial analysis 1. Data exploration: query2. Overlay operation3. Neighbourhood operation4. Network analysis   Lab tutorial 21. Spatial data editing in QGIS;2. Performing spatial analyses;3. Results interpretation   Starting a GIS project1. Key things to consider for setting up a GIS project;2. Introduction to GIS Software available and online resources;3. More about applications4. Q&A
required_readings: Ellen Cromley & Sara McLafferty. (2011). GIS and Public Health (2nd ed.). New York; London: Guilford Press.
recommended_readings: Longley, P. (2011). Geographic information systems & science (3rd ed.). Hoboken, NJ: Wiley.

title: Public Health and Infectious Disease
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health
description: This course aims to bridge virological and bacteriological concepts with laboratory-based public health practices, focusing on the impact of infectious diseases.
outcome: Students should be able to:1. Master basic knowledge of microbiology and immunology2. Discuss vaccinology in depth3. Describe Global programmes for:• Respiratory and gastrointestinal infections• Vaccine access• Antimicrobial resistance • Emerging infectious disease4. Access and appraise information about infectious diseases
syllabus: Microbiology review (Microbes and the Body)   Water- and food- borne diseases   Influenza Viruses   Coronaviruses   Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers   Mid-term examination   Antimicrobial Resistance   Zoonosis and One Health   Advanced Vaccinology   Biosafety and Techniques in Infectious Diseases   Global Disease Control Programs and Policies   Presentations   Final examination
recommended_readings: Public Health Infectious Disease by Lee Shui-shanPublisher: Stanley Ho Centre for Emerging Infectious Diseases

title: Introduction of Bioinformatics
requirements: For TPg students under School of Public Health
description: This course intends to provide an overview of the bioinformatics analyses for health management and epidemiological studies. Content of this course includes to examine the current knowledge and strategy for managing information of patient- and pathogen-specific covariates and genetic information to understand disease progression or host-pathogen interaction. Key issues in i) Genetic Association Studies, ii) Network Analysis, iii) Deep Sequencing Applications and iv) Phylogenetic Analysis will be addressed in this course.

title: Practicum on Infectious Diseases
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health
description: The course offers a learning opportunity to students who are interested in the public health control of infectious diseases in the local context. In addition to learning about the work of the Centre for Health Protection (CHP), Department of Health, the Module coordinator would guide students with discussion and tutorial.
